Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and harms democracy.
It creates two classes of citizens, privileging politicians, journalists, and educational institutions over ordinary citizens.
The bill poses a threat to the democratic power gained by citizens through the Internet.
Determining truth is complex and constantly evolving, making the bill's implementation problematic.
The inclusion of true but potentially misleading information in the scope of removal is concerning.
The bill could inadvertently persecute minorities instead of protecting them.
Delegating legislative power to private entities raises constitutional concerns.
The bill infringes on the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
It creates an unfair division between citizens deemed trustworthy and those labeled untrustworthy.
Notable Quotes: This bill demonstrates a lack of respect for the freedom of speech of Australian citizens and has the potential to significantly harm our democracy.
The Internet has revolutionized democracy by giving regular people a voice. This bill poses a significant threat to the power and influence regular citizens have gained.
Freedom of speech allows for open and honest discussions in which people can be wrong and the truth can be debated.
This presents an unconstitutional abdication of legislative power.
By deplatforming certain views as misinformation, this bill erodes the foundational principles of democracy.
